elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The influences of organic ligands with different binding motifs on the structures and properties of coordination compounds with ZnⅡand N3 - anions have been demonstrated.

      

Highlights

   ⋅ The connecting motif of two different organic ligands have been characterized.   ⋅ The influence of ligands on the structure of complexes with N3 - anions has been demonstrated.   ⋅ The connecting types N3 - anions have been classified.

elements.clean_text:
The connecting motif of two different organic ligands have been characterized.

The influence of ligands on the structure of complexes with N3 - anions has been demonstrated.

The connecting types N3 - anions have been classified.

Abstract

Two zinc (II) pseudo-halide complexes [Zn(L1 )(N3)2]n (1 L1 : 1,2-diaminocyclohexane) and Zn(L2 )2(N3)2 (2 L2 : 4,5-dimethy-2-(pyridine-2-yl) imidazole) have been synthesized and characterized. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that the central ZnII atoms in 1 displays distorted trigonal bipyramidal arrangement with a 1D chain structure bridged by N3 - anions, while in 2, the central ZnII atoms incorporating with two bidentate L2  ligands, and adopts an octahedral geometry and shows a "butterfly" coordination framework. Structural analysis demonstrated that the organic ligands play an important role in determining the resultant structure. In addition, both complexes were further characterized by thermal stability properties and Hirshfeld surface analysis.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Over the past years, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are the subjects of great interest due to their intriguing variety of topologies and structures as well as their enormous potential in many fields, such as magnets, ion-exchange, heterogeneous catalysts, chemical sensing, luminescence and gas storage . Despite the remarkable achievements reached in this aspect so far, the rational control in the construction of coordination frameworks remains a considerable challenge at this stage and much more work is required to extend the knowledge in this field . To a certain degree, the final structures of coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks can be reasonably controlled and directed by combination of various forces such as metal-ligand coordination bond and much weaker interactions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past years, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are the subjects of great interest due to their intriguing variety of topologies and structures as well as their enormous potential in many fields, such as magnets, ion-exchange, heterogeneous catalysts, chemical sensing, luminescence and gas storage . Despite the remarkable achievements reached in this aspect so far, the rational control in the construction of coordination frameworks remains a considerable challenge at this stage and much more work is required to extend the knowledge in this field . To a certain degree, the final structures of coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks can be reasonably controlled and directed by combination of various forces such as metal-ligand coordination bond and much weaker interactions .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In addition, several factors including metals atoms, temperature, the organic anions and N-donor ligands can affect the final structures of coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks . Taking into account the various factors, the choice of the organic ligand is a key factor that affects the construction of coordination compounds with interesting structures . Besides, the skillful introduction of co-ligands into the self-assembly process can also result in completely different structural motifs . Organic N<ce:italic>-</ce:italic>heterocycle ligands are good building blocks for the construction of coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks, because amino groups and multidentate chelating aromatic nitrogen atoms have an excellent coordination capability and versatile coordination modes . Among them, imidazole derivatives are regarded as interesting ligands, because they can adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of the different metal ions . On the other hand, cleavage of the sp<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>C-N bond in cyclohexylamine (87.6 kcal mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> is relatively facile , so it can be used as an excellent multi-functional ligand for the construction of coordination polymers . Additionally, in our previous work, the effect of pseudohalide anions (SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and SeCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) on the spin-crossover of SCO systems was proof and the multidentate 4,5-dimethy-2 -(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole was selected as organic ligand to react with Fe(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition, several factors including metals atoms, temperature, the organic anions and N-donor ligands can affect the final structures of coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks . Taking into account the various factors, the choice of the organic ligand is a key factor that affects the construction of coordination compounds with interesting structures . Besides, the skillful introduction of co-ligands into the self-assembly process can also result in completely different structural motifs . Organic N-heterocycle ligands are good building blocks for the construction of coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks, because amino groups and multidentate chelating aromatic nitrogen atoms have an excellent coordination capability and versatile coordination modes . Among them, imidazole derivatives are regarded as interesting ligands, because they can adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of the different metal ions . On the other hand, cleavage of the sp3C-N bond in cyclohexylamine (87.6kcalmol-1)2 is relatively facile , so it can be used as an excellent multi-functional ligand for the construction of coordination polymers . Additionally, in our previous work, the effect of pseudohalide anions (SCN- and SeCN-) on the spin-crossover of SCO systems was proof and the multidentate 4,5-dimethy-2 -(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole was selected as organic ligand to react with Fe(ClO4)2 .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Taking inspiration from the points mentioned above, we explored organic aromatic ligand 4,5-dimethy-2-(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole as organic ligand (<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>), pseudohalide (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) were selected as co-ligands, beside, saturated N<ce:italic>-</ce:italic>heterocyclic ligand 1, 2-cyclohexanediamine, which can adopt various coordination modes to bind metal centers of specific coordination geometry, is employed as another comparative organic ligand, to react with Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, aiming to further investigate the influence of different types of organic ligands on the structures and properties of coordination compounds. As expected, two new complexes have been obtained [Zn (<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>)(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Zn(<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction results revealed that the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a 1D chain polymer with five-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal arrangement while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is in six-coordinated octahedral geometry. TGA, PXRD and Hirshfeld Surface also were performed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Taking inspiration from the points mentioned above, we explored organic aromatic ligand 4,5-dimethy-2-(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole as organic ligand (L2 ), pseudohalide (N3 -) were selected as co-ligands, beside, saturated N-heterocyclic ligand 1, 2-cyclohexanediamine, which can adopt various coordination modes to bind metal centers of specific coordination geometry, is employed as another comparative organic ligand, to react with Zn(NO3)2, aiming to further investigate the influence of different types of organic ligands on the structures and properties of coordination compounds. As expected, two new complexes have been obtained [Zn (L1 )(N3)2]n (1) and Zn(L2 )2(N3) (2) ( ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction results revealed that the 1 displays a 1D chain polymer with five-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal arrangement while 2 is in six-coordinated octahedral geometry. TGA, PXRD and Hirshfeld Surface also were performed.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of complex 1

The asymmetric coordination unit of complex 1 composed of one central ZnII ion, one L1  ligand and two N3 - ions. As can be seen in  b, the each central ZnII ion is five-coordinated in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with five N atoms, two from L1  ligands [Zn1-N2: 2.078(2) and Zn1-N1 2.019(3) Å] and three from N3 - ligands [Zn1-N6: 2.237(3) Å, Zn1-N8=2.306(3) Å, Zn1-N3: 1.974(3) Å]. Where, the axial positions are occupied by N1, N2 and N3 with the N1-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 137.14 (2), N2-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 136.21 (3) and the equatorial mean plane is slightly distorted with N6-Zn1-N8 bond angle of 175.34 (19). The L1  ligand behaves as the bidentate ligand via two amino groups, and N3 - co-ligands bridge the adjacent central ZnII ions affording a 1D chain structure with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 6.310(1)Å (b). The N3 - anions use two different types of bridging modes. One N3 - behaves as the terminal ligand, adopting the EO-bridged azide pairs binding mode; the other N3 - behaves as the EE-bridged azides with N6-Zn-N8 into an infinited 1D chains forming a coordination polymer, additionally, these adjacent 1D chains are further connected via NH…N hydrogen bonding interaction between coordinated amino group of L1  ligand and the uncoordinated N atoms of N3 - ions as well as CH…C weak interaction to resulting in 3D layered structure (c) ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">Crystal structure of complex 2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes as colorless block crystals in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic> space group, the asymmetric unit (ASU) consisting of a Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, two N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions, and two ligands <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a) displays a ‘‘batterfly-like” motif. In the crystal, each Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion adopts a distorted six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry surrounded by four N atoms originating from ligands <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> liking two wings and two N atoms from N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions which just similar to two antennae. Every ‘‘batterfly” motif packed into 1D chains through N3<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N6 solitary electrons contacts (b), and the 1D chains then stacked into 3D motif (c) by C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>π and π…π weaker interactions. For the ‘‘batterfly-like” unit, the average Zn-N distance is 1.9665 Ǻ (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>) which is significantly shorter than which has been reported complexes . Besides, the N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion is almost linear [N7-N8-N20, 177.47(7)], whereas the Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N (N) linkages are slightly bent [Zn1-N7-N8, 119.23(5)]. In addition, the selected bond distances and angles of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are tabulated in  and geometrical parameters for hydrogen bonds are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of complex 2

Complex 2 crystallizes as colorless block crystals in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group, the asymmetric unit (ASU) consisting of a ZnII ion, two N3 - ions, and two ligands L2  ( a) displays a ‘‘batterfly-like" motif. In the crystal, each ZnII ion adopts a distorted six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry surrounded by four N atoms originating from ligands L2  liking two wings and two N atoms from N3 - ions which just similar to two antennae. Every ‘‘batterfly" motif packed into 1D chains through N3…N6 solitary electrons contacts (b), and the 1D chains then stacked into 3D motif (c) by CH…π and π…π weaker interactions. For the ‘‘batterfly-like" unit, the average Zn-N distance is 1.9665 Ǻ ( ) which is significantly shorter than which has been reported complexes . Besides, the N3 - ion is almost linear [N7-N8-N20, 177.47(7)], whereas the ZnNN (N) linkages are slightly bent [Zn1-N7-N8, 119.23(5)]. In addition, the selected bond distances and angles of complexes 1, 2 are tabulated in  and geometrical parameters for hydrogen bonds are shown in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st045">Structural discussion of complexes 1 and 2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained via the assembly of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and azido (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) with the presence of ligand <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> respectively, affording different coordination modes and supramolecular lattices, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), respectively. In complexes, the central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion adopts five- and six-coordinated forming two different distorted arrangement, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry, for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, resulting from the different N<ce:italic>-</ce:italic>heterocycles donor organic ligands which <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> belongs to saturated, whereas <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> is a part of aromatic compounds. It implies the saturation of N-donor ligands can influence coordination modes of compounds. Besides, it should be noted that the N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions represent two kinds of binding modes (EO and EE bridged model) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and only adopts EO bridged model forming the monodentate coordination fashions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As a result, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows an infinite 1D coordination polymer and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays mononuclear metal-organic framework compound. These structural distinguish may be ascribed to the distinct coordination ability and steric bulk of the N<ce:italic>-</ce:italic>heterocyclic ligands (<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural discussion of complexes 1 and 2

Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained via the assembly of Zn(NO3)2 and azido (N3 -) with the presence of ligand L1 , L2  respectively, affording different coordination modes and supramolecular lattices, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), respectively. In complexes, the central ZnII ion adopts five- and six-coordinated forming two different distorted arrangement, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry, for compounds 1, 2, resulting from the different N-heterocycles donor organic ligands which L1  belongs to saturated, whereas L2  is a part of aromatic compounds. It implies the saturation of N-donor ligands can influence coordination modes of compounds. Besides, it should be noted that the N3 - anions represent two kinds of binding modes (EO and EE bridged model) in 1 and only adopts EO bridged model forming the monodentate coordination fashions in 2. As a result, compound 1 shows an infinite 1D coordination polymer and 2 displays mononuclear metal-organic framework compound. These structural distinguish may be ascribed to the distinct coordination ability and steric bulk of the N-heterocyclic ligands (L1  and L2 ).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Hirshfeld surface</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Hirshfeld surface is a powerful tool for the identification of intermolecular interactions. The 3D dnorm values are mapped onto a red-blue-white color Hirshfeld surface and red regions represent closer contacts, blue regions represent longer contacts and white regions represent the distance of contacts which is exactly the vdW separation. What is more, the 3D dnorm can be converted into 2D fingerprint plots, which we can analysis the intermolecular contacts and get a quantitative summary of the nature and type of intermolecular contacts .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Hirshfeld surface

Hirshfeld surface is a powerful tool for the identification of intermolecular interactions. The 3D dnorm values are mapped onto a red-blue-white color Hirshfeld surface and red regions represent closer contacts, blue regions represent longer contacts and white regions represent the distance of contacts which is exactly the vdW separation. What is more, the 3D dnorm can be converted into 2D fingerprint plots, which we can analysis the intermolecular contacts and get a quantitative summary of the nature and type of intermolecular contacts .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The 3D Hirshfeld surface (dnorm) and 2D fingerprint plots of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the red regions on the dnorm surface represent the significant N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N hydrogen bonding interactions, which represent the closest intermolecular interactions in the crystal. The small red points on the dnorm surfaces are corresponding to the significant N4-Zn interaction, which due to the close approach of an N atom of azide anion to the central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion. And the blue regions represent the H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>H interactions. Obviously, the blue regions occupy the most of Hirshfeld surface about 35.8% to the total Hirshfeld surfaces. Actually, the proportion of N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N and N<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Zn interaction calculated by two-dimensional (2D) fingerprint plot are found to be 47.3%, and 1.8% to the total Hirshfeld surfaces of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is consistent with the analysis of the crystal structure. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the larger red regions on the upper right and bottom right of the dnorm surfaces are corresponding to the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N weak hydrogen bonding and N<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N interactions which have a great significant contribution to the total Hirshfeld surfaces with comprise of 36.4%, 2.2%, respectively, to the total Hirshfeld surfaces. Interestingly, N<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Zn interactions are found only in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and C<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>H intermolecular interactions exist only in compound <ce:bold>2.</ce:bold> These differences of the interaction in the crystal structures of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> also are clearly shown in  and . Apart from those above, the presence of H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>H, N<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N and C<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N intermolecular interactions are observed, and the percentages of them are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The 3D Hirshfeld surface (dnorm) and 2D fingerprint plots of complex 1 and 2 are shown in  . In complex 1, the red regions on the dnorm surface represent the significant NH…N hydrogen bonding interactions, which represent the closest intermolecular interactions in the crystal. The small red points on the dnorm surfaces are corresponding to the significant N4-Zn interaction, which due to the close approach of an N atom of azide anion to the central ZnII ion. And the blue regions represent the H…H interactions. Obviously, the blue regions occupy the most of Hirshfeld surface about 35.8% to the total Hirshfeld surfaces. Actually, the proportion of NH…N and N…Zn interaction calculated by two-dimensional (2D) fingerprint plot are found to be 47.3%, and 1.8% to the total Hirshfeld surfaces of complex 1, which is consistent with the analysis of the crystal structure. In complex 2, the larger red regions on the upper right and bottom right of the dnorm surfaces are corresponding to the CH…N weak hydrogen bonding and N…N interactions which have a great significant contribution to the total Hirshfeld surfaces with comprise of 36.4%, 2.2%, respectively, to the total Hirshfeld surfaces. Interestingly, N…Zn interactions are found only in compound 1, and C…H intermolecular interactions exist only in compound 2. These differences of the interaction in the crystal structures of compounds 1, 2 also are clearly shown in  and . Apart from those above, the presence of H…H, N…N and C…N intermolecular interactions are observed, and the percentages of them are summarized in  .

</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> are investigated on a Proteus Thermal analyse system (from NETZSCH TG 2009 F3) and the heating rate is around 20 K min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> with the temperature range of 30–600 °C. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor> shows the TGA traces of them. For complex <ce:bold>1,</ce:bold> the complex keeps stable up to 292 °C and then suffers a sharp weight loss until heating to 330 °C, which is due to the decomposition of the ligands with mass loss of 38.52% (the calculated ratio is 42.48%) to give the Zn(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> residue. With regard to complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the thermal profile of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is different from the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the abrupt weight loss of the main framework occurs from 359 °C, by the mass decomposition of two ligands about 70.38% (the calculated ratio is 69.83%). In addition, the phase purities of the complexes are also identified by PXRD patterns, which show the essential difference to diverse central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion distorted arrangement (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal study

The thermal behaviors of complexes L1  and L2  are investigated on a Proteus Thermal analyse system (from NETZSCH TG 2009 F3) and the heating rate is around 20Kmin-1 with the temperature range of 30-600°C.   shows the TGA traces of them. For complex 1, the complex keeps stable up to 292°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss until heating to 330°C, which is due to the decomposition of the ligands with mass loss of 38.52% (the calculated ratio is 42.48%) to give the Zn(N3)2 residue. With regard to complex 2, the thermal profile of 2 is different from the 1, the abrupt weight loss of the main framework occurs from 359°C, by the mass decomposition of two ligands about 70.38% (the calculated ratio is 69.83%). In addition, the phase purities of the complexes are also identified by PXRD patterns, which show the essential difference to diverse central ZnII ion distorted arrangement ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st060">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In summary, two new zinc (II) coordination complexes, [Zn(<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>)(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and Zn(<ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Single-crystal X-ray analysis show structural diversity in both complexes essentially arising from the usage of different ligands resulting in different central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion distorted arrangement, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry, respectively. In addition, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the characteristic Zn<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N interaction. Systematic exploration of the significant ligands effect with other metal atoms as well as pseudo-halide ions is currently underway and this work will contribute to further insights in the rational design of coordination complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two new zinc (II) coordination complexes, [Zn(L1 )(N3)2]n (1) and Zn(L2 )2(N3)2 (2), have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Single-crystal X-ray analysis show structural diversity in both complexes essentially arising from the usage of different ligands resulting in different central ZnII ion distorted arrangement, trigonal bipyramidal and octahedral geometry, respectively. In addition, complex 1 exhibits the characteristic Zn…N interaction. Systematic exploration of the significant ligands effect with other metal atoms as well as pseudo-halide ions is currently underway and this work will contribute to further insights in the rational design of coordination complexes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st065">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st070">Materials and physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">All reagents were obtained commercially, and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a NETZSCH TG 2009 F3 system at a heating rate of 20 K min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen flowing at 20 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> over the range from 50 to 600 °C. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed using a Vario-EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction was recorded on a D8 ADVANCE XRD (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) at 40 mA and 45 kV. The sample was packed into a glass holder and diffraction patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5–50, at a scan rate of 3° min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and physical measurements

All reagents were obtained commercially, and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a NETZSCH TG 2009 F3 system at a heating rate of 20Kmin-1 under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen flowing at 20cm3min-1 over the range from 50 to 600°C. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen were performed using a Vario-EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction was recorded on a D8 ADVANCE XRD (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å) at 40mA and 45kV. The sample was packed into a glass holder and diffraction patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5-50, at a scan rate of 3°min-1.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of L2  (4,5-dimethy-2-(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole)

The synthetic routes of the ligand L2  are illustrated in  . 1ml oxalylchloride (10mmol) was added dropwise to a CH2Cl2 solution (100ml) with 1.5gN-methylacetamide (20mmol) at 0°C under heavy gas evolution. After stirred for about 30min, 2-pyridine carboxamide (2.74g, 10mmol) was added. The obtained mixture was stirred for 3h at rt, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in an aqueous solution of NaHCO3 (60ml) and refluxed for a further 2h at 100°C. The water phase was extracted three times with CHCl3. The organic phase was concentrated and re-crystallized from MeOH gave the ligand L2 . Yield: 1.14g, ca. 78%. Elemental analysis (%) for L2  (C10H11N3): Calc.: C, 69.34; H, 6.40; N, 24.25; found: C, 69.27; H, 6.44; N, 24.19%. IR (KBr, cm1): 3048, 2980, 2180, 1750, 1560, 1562, 1533, 1482, 1340, 1269, 1235, 1120, 1040, 1015, 987, 960, 798, 747, 721. 1H NMR d: 2.67-2.75 (d, 6H), 7.36 (m, H), 7.85 (m, 1H), 8.38 (d, 1H), 8.59 (d, 1H), 13.00 (s, 1H). 13C NMR d: 12.6, 43.5, 124.5, 125.6, 131.6, 137.2, 143.4, 149.2, 155.1, 165.9.

</ce:italic> (0.8 mmol) in MeOH (10 ml) was added. The mixture was added into an aqueous solution containing NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.8 mmol) under continuous stirring (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). After stirring for about 30 min, the solution which results from the mixture was filtered off and allowed to evaporate at room temperature. Crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal diffraction or PXRD were obtained within two weeks and collected by filtration. Yield: ca. 85%. Elemental analysis (%) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>Zn): Calc.: C, 27.33; H, 0.38; N, 42.51; found: C, 27.43; H, 0.78; N, 42.52%. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is synthesized using a similar method (C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>Zn): Calc.: C, 48.63; H, 4.08; N, 34.04; found: C, 48.65; H, 4.10; N, 34.24%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes 1 and 2

To a solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.4mmol) in MeOH (10ml), a solution of ligand L1  (0.8mmol) in MeOH (10ml) was added. The mixture was added into an aqueous solution containing NaN3 (0.8mmol) under continuous stirring ( ). After stirring for about 30min, the solution which results from the mixture was filtered off and allowed to evaporate at room temperature. Crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal diffraction or PXRD were obtained within two weeks and collected by filtration. Yield: ca. 85%. Elemental analysis (%) for 1 (C6H14N8Zn): Calc.: C, 27.33; H, 0.38; N, 42.51; found: C, 27.43; H, 0.78; N, 42.52%. Complex 2 is synthesized using a similar method (C20H20N12Zn): Calc.: C, 48.63; H, 4.08; N, 34.04; found: C, 48.65; H, 4.10; N, 34.24%.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">X-ray crystallographic study</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected with graphite-monochromated Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.071073 nm). A Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer with the v-scan technique was used . The lattice parameters were integrated using vector analysis and refined from the diffraction matrix, the absorption correction was carried out by using Bruker SADABS program with the multi-scan method. The structures were solved by full-matrix least-squares methods on all <ce:italic>F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> data. The SHELXS-2014 and SHELXL-2014 programs  were used for structure solution and structure refinement, respectively. The molecular graphics were prepared by using the mercury program .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of complexes 1 and 2 were collected with graphite-monochromated Mo Ka radiation (λ=0.071073nm). A Rigaku SCXmini diffractometer with the v-scan technique was used . The lattice parameters were integrated using vector analysis and refined from the diffraction matrix, the absorption correction was carried out by using Bruker SADABS program with the multi-scan method. The structures were solved by full-matrix least-squares methods on all F2  data. The SHELXS-2014 and SHELXL-2014 programs  were used for structure solution and structure refinement, respectively. The molecular graphics were prepared by using the mercury program .

Synthesis of L2  (4,5-dimethy-2-(pyridine-2-yl)imidazole)

The synthetic routes of the ligand L2  are illustrated in  . 1ml oxalylchloride (10mmol) was added dropwise to a CH2Cl2 solution (100ml) with 1.5gN-methylacetamide (20mmol) at 0°C under heavy gas evolution. After stirred for about 30min, 2-pyridine carboxamide (2.74g, 10mmol) was added. The obtained mixture was stirred for 3h at rt, and the volatiles were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was dissolved in an aqueous solution of NaHCO3 (60ml) and refluxed for a further 2h at 100°C. The water phase was extracted three times with CHCl3. The organic phase was concentrated and re-crystallized from MeOH gave the ligand L2 . Yield: 1.14g, ca. 78%. Elemental analysis (%) for L2  (C10H11N3): Calc.: C, 69.34; H, 6.40; N, 24.25; found: C, 69.27; H, 6.44; N, 24.19%. IR (KBr, cm1): 3048, 2980, 2180, 1750, 1560, 1562, 1533, 1482, 1340, 1269, 1235, 1120, 1040, 1015, 987, 960, 798, 747, 721. 1H NMR d: 2.67-2.75 (d, 6H), 7.36 (m, H), 7.85 (m, 1H), 8.38 (d, 1H), 8.59 (d, 1H), 13.00 (s, 1H). 13C NMR d: 12.6, 43.5, 124.5, 125.6, 131.6, 137.2, 143.4, 149.2, 155.1, 165.9.

Synthesis of complexes 1 and 2

To a solution of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.4mmol) in MeOH (10ml), a solution of ligand L1  (0.8mmol) in MeOH (10ml) was added. The mixture was added into an aqueous solution containing NaN3 (0.8mmol) under continuous stirring ( ). After stirring for about 30min, the solution which results from the mixture was filtered off and allowed to evaporate at room temperature. Crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal diffraction or PXRD were obtained within two weeks and collected by filtration. Yield: ca. 85%. <ce:section-title id="st030">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Crystal structure of complex 1</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The asymmetric coordination unit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> composed of one central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, one <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ligand and two N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions. As can be seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>b, the each central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is five-coordinated in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with five N atoms, two from <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ligands [Zn1-N2: 2.078(2) and Zn1-N1 2.019(3) Å] and three from N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands [Zn1-N6: 2.237(3) Å, Zn1-N8 = 2.306(3) Å, Zn1-N3: 1.974(3) Å]. Where, the axial positions are occupied by N1, N2 and N3 with the N1-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 137.14 (2), N2-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 136.21 (3) and the equatorial mean plane is slightly distorted with N6-Zn1-N8 bond angle of 175.34 (19). The <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ligand behaves as the bidentate ligand via two amino groups, and N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> co-ligands bridge the adjacent central Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions affording a 1D chain structure with the Zn<ce:bold>···</ce:bold>Zn distance of 6.310(1)Å (b). The N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions use two different types of bridging modes. One N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> behaves as the terminal ligand, adopting the EO-bridged azide pairs binding mode; the other N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> behaves as the EE-bridged azides with N6-Zn-N8 into an infinited 1D chains forming a coordination polymer, additionally, these adjacent 1D chains are further connected via N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N hydrogen bonding interaction between coordinated amino group of <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ligand and the uncoordinated N atoms of N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions as well as C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>C weak interaction to resulting in 3D layered structure (c) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st040">Crystal structure of complex 2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes as colorless block crystals in the orthorhombic <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic> space group, the asymmetric unit (ASU) consisting of a Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, two N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions, and two ligands <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a) displays a ‘‘batterfly-like” motif. In the crystal, each Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion adopts a distorted six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry surrounded by four N atoms originating from ligands <ce:italic>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> liking two wings and two N atoms from N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions which just similar to two antennae. Every ‘‘batterfly” motif packed into 1D chains through N3<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N6 solitary electrons contacts (b), and the 1D chains then stacked into 3D motif (c) by C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>π and π…π weaker interactions. For the ‘‘batterfly-like” unit, the average Zn-N distance is 1.9665 Ǻ (

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of complex 1

The asymmetric coordination unit of complex 1 composed of one central ZnII ion, one L1  ligand and two N3 - ions. As can be seen in  b, the each central ZnII ion is five-coordinated in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment with five N atoms, two from L1  ligands [Zn1-N2: 2.078(2) and Zn1-N1 2.019(3) Å] and three from N3 - ligands [Zn1-N6: 2.237(3) Å, Zn1-N8=2.306(3) Å, Zn1-N3: 1.974(3) Å]. Where, the axial positions are occupied by N1, N2 and N3 with the N1-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 137.14 (2), N2-Zn1-N3 bond angle of 136.21 (3) and the equatorial mean plane is slightly distorted with N6-Zn1-N8 bond angle of 175.34 (19). The L1  ligand behaves as the bidentate ligand via two amino groups, and N3 - co-ligands bridge the adjacent central ZnII ions affording a 1D chain structure with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 6.310(1)Å (b). The N3 - anions use two different types of bridging modes. One N3 - behaves as the terminal ligand, adopting the EO-bridged azide pairs binding mode; the other N3 - behaves as the EE-bridged azides with N6-Zn-N8 into an infinited 1D chains forming a coordination polymer, additionally, these adjacent 1D chains are further connected via NH…N hydrogen bonding interaction between coordinated amino group of L1  ligand and the uncoordinated N atoms of N3 - ions as well as CH…C weak interaction to resulting in 3D layered structure (c) ( ).

Crystal structure of complex 2

Complex 2 crystallizes as colorless block crystals in the orthorhombic Pbcn space group, the asymmetric unit (ASU) consisting of a ZnII ion, two N3 - ions, and two ligands L2  ( a) displays a ‘‘batterfly-like" motif. In the crystal, each ZnII ion adopts a distorted six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry surrounded by four N atoms originating from ligands L2  liking two wings and two N atoms from N3 - ions which just similar to two antennae. Every ‘‘batterfly" motif packed into 1D chains through N3…N6 solitary electrons contacts (b), and the 1D chains then stacked into 3D motif (c) by CH…π and π…π weaker interactions. For the ‘‘batterfly-like" unit, the average Zn-N distance is 1.9665 Ǻ ( ) which is significantly shorter than which has been reported complexes . Besides, the N3 - ion is almost linear [N7-N8-N20, 177.47(7)], whereas the ZnNN (N) linkages are slightly bent [Zn1-N7-N8, 119.23(5)]. In addition, the selected bond distances and angles of complexes 1, 2 are tabulated in  and geometrical parameters for hydrogen bonds are shown in  .

Thermal study

The thermal behaviors of complexes L1  and L2  are investigated on a Proteus Thermal analyse system (from NETZSCH TG 2009 F3) and the heating rate is around 20Kmin-1 with the temperature range of 30-600°C.   shows the TGA traces of them. For complex 1, the complex keeps stable up to 292°C and then suffers a sharp weight loss until heating to 330°C, which is due to the decomposition of the ligands with mass loss of 38.52% (the calculated ratio is 42.48%) to give the Zn(N3)2 residue. With regard to complex 2, the thermal profile of 2 is different from the 1, the abrupt weight loss of the main framework occurs from 359°C, by the mass decomposition of two ligands about 70.38% (the calculated ratio is 69.83%). In addition, the phase purities of the complexes are also identified by PXRD patterns, which show the essential difference to diverse central ZnII ion distorted arrangement ( ).
